results.title: Hannibal (D) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ridley Scott, Dino De Laurentiis, Martha De Laurentiis, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Universal Studios
results.brief_description: Based on the controversial sequel novel, “Hannibal” is the follow-up film to “Silence of the Lambs”. After ten years of hiding following his escape from custody, Hannibal Lecter, a feared and cunning serial killer, resurfaces to toy with FBI agent Clarice Starling. As Starling’s career flounders thanks to an ill-fated drug bust, Lecter attempts to elude an Italian police detective who has cottoned on to Lecter’s true identity. We are also introduced to a maimed and wealthy former victim of Lecter’s, Mason Verger, who plots to avenge the doctor in a most grisly and unusual manner. Cast includes: Anthony Hopkins, Julianne Moore, Ray Liotta, Frankie R. Faison, Giancarlo Giannini and Gary Oldman (uncredited and unrecognisable as Mason Verger).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ridley Scott, Dino De Laurentiis, Martha De Laurentiis, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Universal Studios

results.title: Les Belles de Nuit = Beauties of the Night
results.brief_description:
Claude, an impoverished music teacher, lives a life of boredom in a small provincial town. His lovely young neighbour seems smitten, but he has little time for her. Each sound he hears or every person he meets begets a new fancy. He dreams himself a conquering hero, a musketeer, or a soldier of the French Revolution, but always the conquerer of delicious women. The conflict between waking and dream worlds leads to amusing, strange, even fantastic situations. Which world will prevail?

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair, Pierre Barrillet, Jean-Pierre Gredy ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Georges van Parys ; art direction, Leon Barsacq ; costumes, Rosine Delamare ; assistant director, Mic
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Gina Lollobrigida, Jean Paredes, Martine carol, Raymond Bussieres, Magali de Vendeuil, Bernard Lajarrigue, Marylin Bufferd, Pierre Palau, Jane Pierson.

results.title: Le Dernier Milliardaire = the Last Millionaire
results.brief_description:
Le Dernier Milliardaire’ tells the story of a small mythical European country, Casinario, suddenly subjected to the whims of a mad dictator. Tobis Klangfilm refused to bankroll the project on political grounds, worried it could be considered a commentary on Hitler’s recent seizure of power in Germany. (Clair’s script also contained some fairly overt parodic references to Mussolini.) And so the (by now financially ailing) Pathe-Natan company had the bad fortune to produce what most observers consider the one complete failure among all of Clair’s works, a film scorned by audiences and critics alike as unfunny, tasteless, and cinematographically inept, although it is a sheer delight today. Unnerved by this commercial disaster, Clair left France for an artistic exile in England and, during the war years, the United States. It would be thirteen eventful years before his return to the French cinema, as an old master in the postwar ‘Tradition de Qualite’. Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Rudolph Mate, Louis Nee ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand, Lucien Carre.
Cast: Max Dearly, Renee Saint-Cyr, Marthe Mellot, Jose Noguero, Charles Redgie, Jean Sinoel, Raymond Cordy, Christian Argentin, Marcel Carpentier.

results.title: Sans Mobile Apparent = No Apparent Motive
results.brief_description:
It all starts with the bold murder of a well-heeled Frenchman. Commissaire Carella assigned to the case is most puzzled for there seems to be no motive. Then an old man and an astrologer are killed in exactly the same way, leaving the detective to figure out how the three disparate victims are linked. All he has to go on is a mysterious diary given to him by the step daughter of the first victim and containing a list of the man’s lovers.

Credits: Producers, Jacques-Eric Strauss ; director, Philippe Labro ; writers, Philippe Labro, Jacques Lanzmann ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Ennio Morricone.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Dominique Sanda, Sacha Distel, Carla Gravina, Erich Segal, Gilles Segal, Laura Antonelli, Paul Crauchet, Stephane Audran, Jean-Pierre Marielle.

results.title: The Boy who turned yellow
results.creator_credit: Michael Powell, Roger Cherrill and Children's Film Foundation
results.brief_description: John (Mark Dightam) and his class go on a school trip to the Tower of London. While he is there he loses his pet mouse and vows to return and find her later. Back in school, he is not very attentive and falls asleep during a lesson about electricity so his teacher sends him home. On the ‘tube’ there is a sudden flash and John, the train and everyone on it has turned yellow. With the help of Nick - short for ‘Electronic’ (Robert Eddison) John learns about electricity, invades the Tower of London and saves his pet mouse…or was it a dream! Original story and screenplay by Emeric Pressburger. Cast also includes Helen Weir and Brian Worth.

results.title: The Red violin = Le Violon rouge = Violino rosso, Il
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman, Mikado Film Srl (Rome), Red Violin Productions and Sidecar Films and TV
results.brief_description: A five part tale which tells the life story of an exquisite 300 year old violin. The film begins with the loving creation of the instrument in 17th century in Italy by a master craftsman for his unborn child. However, upon the death of the baby the instrument maker curses the violin by adding a secret ingredient to the varnish. The central focus is at an auction house in Montreal where the legendary violin is for sale and the bidding is fierce. The focus of the film is not so much the violin’s future, but its affect on the five lives of those who played it over the years, as we are drawn back into each of their worlds. Coveted by child prodigies, virtuosos and gypsies, the instrument is a poisoned chalice with most of the people who play it meeting a tragic and untimely end. This ambitious film is shot in Cremona, Vienna, Oxford, Shanghai and Montreal, with dialogue in French, English, Italian, Spanish and Mandarin. An Academy Award winning musical soundtrack composed by John Corigliano reminds us of the beauty of the violin as the viewer follows its travels across time and space. Written by Don McKellar and Francois Girard.

results.title: The Quiet man
results.creator_credit: John Ford and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Set in Ireland in the 1820s, this is the story of Irish-born American Sean Thornton (John Wayne) who, after a long and profitable career as a boxer, returns home to settle down and forget a tragic accident in the boxing ring which killed his opponent. Sean buys back his ancestral home, Thornton Cottage, much to the disgust of the neighbouring squire, Red Will Danaher (Victor McLagen). To further complicate matters, Sean has fallen in love with Red Will’s sister, Mary Kate (Maureen O’Hara). Sean must battle against all manner of Irish blarney to get the hand of the girl he loves. This amusing romantic comedy was a change of pace for John Wayne (and John Ford) at the time, although the movie is usually remembered for the fight scene between the characters of O’Hara and Wayne which culminates in him dragging her across a field followed by the entire village.

results.title: La Femme de Ma Vie = Woman in My Life
results.brief_description:
Simon is a virtuoso violonist and an alcoholic. One night, he collapses during a live-to-air TV concert. Following the incident, he is submerged with shame and avoids his wife, Laura. Laura is the women to whom Simon owes his career ever since she set up and managed the orcherstra Simon plays in. In the depth of his crisis, Simon meets Bernard who has been through the same experiences. As Bernard undertakes to heal Simon he unwittingly becomes Laura’s rival who cannot accept to see Simon receiving assistance from anybody but her. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) - Best New Director of a Feature Film 1987.

Credits: Producer, Yannick Bernard ; director, Regis Wargnier ; writers, Catherine Cohen, Alain Le Henry, Regis Wargnier, Alain Wermus ; photography, Francois Catonne ; music, Romano Musumura.
Cast: Christophe Malavoy, Jane Birkin, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Beatrice Agenin, Elsa Lunghini, Florent Pagny, Dominique Blanc, Didier Sandre, Andrzej Seweryn.

results.title: The Crisis = La Crise
results.creator_credit: Coline Serreau, Alain Sarde, Les Films Alain Sarde and TFI Films
results.brief_description: A heartfelt French comedy whose warmth and humour is matched equally by its biting and poignant commentary on social, political and racial issues in France in the early 1990s. Victor (Vincent Lindon), a smart and successful lawyer, is deserted by his wife and fired on the same day. He turns to his colleagues, his friends, his family, but all have troubled and complex lives and have no time to deal with his as well. Enter Michou (Patrick Timsit), a wandering barfly who attaches himself to Victor, both comedic and wise in the effect he has on the lives he touches and most of all on Victor and on the journey through which his sudden crisis takes him. Through their interaction with each other and those around them, brief or lasting, and the humorous antics that befall the unlikely pair, Serreau constructs a striking fairy tale with a subtle political, social and racial critique that confronts the dual existence of humanity and hypocrisy in its many forms in contemporary society. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Love my dog
results.creator_credit: Robert F. McGowan, Hal Roach and Hal Roach Studios
results.brief_description: Silent slapstick comedy featuring “Our Gang” and their efforts to prevent Farina’s beloved pooch being caught and put down by a dog-catcher. Cast includes Joe Cobb, Jackie Condon, Dick Gilbert, Allen “Farina” Hoskins, Scooter Lowry. Silent film with English captions.
